> üòü *Oh no, looks like it's a minor cut! Don't worry ‚Äî stay calm.*
ü©π *Here's what you can do step-by-step:*



> 1Ô∏è‚É£ Wash your hands properly.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Clean the wound gently with water.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Apply antiseptic.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Cover with a clean bandage.



**üí° And remember, if it starts looking red or swollen later, see a doctor.**

‚ö†Ô∏è *This looks serious. Please don‚Äôt panic ‚Äî just follow these steps quickly:*

1Ô∏è‚É£ **Apply firm pressure** on the wound using a clean cloth or bandage.
2Ô∏è‚É£ **Do not lift the cloth** to check ‚Äî if it soaks, place another one on top.
3Ô∏è‚É£ **Raise the injured area** above the heart level, if possible.
4Ô∏è‚É£ **Keep the person still and calm.**
5Ô∏è‚É£ If bleeding doesn‚Äôt stop within **10 minutes**,

or it‚Äôs **spurting**,
üëâ **Call emergency services immediately.**

üòÆ *Nosebleeds can be scary, but they‚Äôre usually not dangerous. Stay calm ‚Äî I‚Äôll guide you!*

1Ô∏è‚É£ **Sit upright** and **lean slightly forward**. Don‚Äôt lie down.
2Ô∏è‚É£ **Pinch the soft part of your nose**, just below the bridge.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Hold it **firmly for 10 minutes** ‚Äî breathe through your mouth.
4Ô∏è‚É£ You can place a **cold pack** on the back of the neck or bridge of the nose.

‚ö†Ô∏è *Do NOT tilt your head back or lie flat ‚Äî it can cause blood to go down the throat.*

‚è±Ô∏è *If bleeding doesn‚Äôt stop after 15‚Äì20 minutes,*
üëâ *Seek medical help immediately.*
Is it a Burn or Electrocution
I didn't catch that. Select a valid option:

**Oh no! A burn can really hurt. Here's what you should do right away:**

1Ô∏è‚É£ Cool the area with clean, running water for 10‚Äì20 minutes.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Don‚Äôt use ice, butter, oil, or toothpaste ‚Äî they can make it worse.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Gently apply aloe vera gel or a clean, non-sticky dressing.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Take a mild painkiller if needed.
üö® If blisters form or the burn is large, please seek medical help.

**‚ö° Stay calm ‚Äî electrical injuries can be serious. Follow these steps:**

1Ô∏è‚É£ Don‚Äôt touch the person if they‚Äôre still in contact with power!
2Ô∏è‚É£ Turn off the power source (main switch or unplug if safe).
3Ô∏è‚É£ Once safe, check if they‚Äôre conscious and breathing.
4Ô∏è‚É£ If unresponsive, start CPR if trained.
üöë Call emergency services immediately.
‚úÖ Even if they seem fine, they need to see a doctor.
Got it ‚Äî you're dealing with a muscle or bone injury. Let's figure out the best steps. Please select:
I didn't catch that. Select a valid option:

**ü¶∂ A sprain or strain? No worries ‚Äî follow the R.I.C.E. method:**

üîπ Rest: Stop using the injured area.
üîπ Ice: Apply an ice pack (wrapped in cloth) for 15‚Äì20 mins every 2‚Äì3 hours.
üîπ Compression: Use an elastic bandage to reduce swelling.
üîπ Elevation: Raise the injured limb above heart level.

‚ö†Ô∏è If swelling doesn‚Äôt go down or you can't move it, see a doctor.

**ü¶¥ Suspect a fracture? Act carefully:**

1Ô∏è‚É£ Don‚Äôt move the injured area.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Support it using a splint or soft padding.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Apply ice to reduce swelling (avoid placing directly on skin).
4Ô∏è‚É£ Call for medical help or go to the nearest hospital.

‚ùå Do not try to straighten the bone or push it back.

**üí™ Dislocation can be painful ‚Äî here's what to do:**

1Ô∏è‚É£ Don‚Äôt try to pop the joint back in!
2Ô∏è‚É£ Support the area in a comfortable position using a sling.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Apply ice to reduce pain and swelling.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Get medical help immediately.

‚úÖ Keep the person still and calm.

üò£ **Cramp? Let‚Äôs ease it out:**

1Ô∏è‚É£ Gently stretch the muscle (e.g., leg stretch for leg cramp).
2Ô∏è‚É£ Massage the area slowly.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Apply a warm towel or heating pad.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Drink water ‚Äî cramps can be due to dehydration.

If cramps are frequent, the person should consult a doctor.

eq.value: Intrusion in Eye, Ear, Nose, or Skin

concat.scalar:
**üëÅÔ∏è Got something in the eye? Here's what to do:**

1Ô∏è‚É£ Do NOT rub the eye.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Blink rapidly or gently flush the eye with clean water or saline.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Tilt head and pour water from the inner corner outward.
4Ô∏è‚É£ If it doesn't come out or causes pain, cover the eye lightly and see a doctor.

‚ö†Ô∏è Never try to remove a stuck object with fingers or tools.

**üëÇ Something stuck in the ear? Follow this:**

1Ô∏è‚É£ Don't poke or insert anything inside.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Tilt the head and gently shake ‚Äî sometimes it falls out.
3Ô∏è‚É£ For bugs: turn the ear upward and pour a little warm (not hot) oil to float it out.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Still stuck? Visit a doctor. Don‚Äôt delay.

‚ö†Ô∏è Trying to remove it forcefully can cause damage.

**ü©π Got a splinter or glass piece in the skin?**

1Ô∏è‚É£ Wash your hands and the area with soap.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Use clean tweezers to gently pull it out if visible.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Clean again and apply antiseptic & bandage.
4Ô∏è‚É£ If deeply embedded or painful ‚Äî see a doctor.

‚ö†Ô∏è Don‚Äôt dig into the skin to remove hidden objects.

**üëÉ Object in the nose? Try this:**

1Ô∏è‚É£ Ask the person to breathe through the mouth.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Gently blow the nose while closing the other nostril.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Don‚Äôt use tweezers or poke inside.
4Ô∏è‚É£ If it doesn‚Äôt come out ‚Äî head to a doctor immediately.

üö´ Avoid using any liquids or sprays without medical advice.

Oh ! it's an insect bite or sting, do this calmly. 

1Ô∏è‚É£ **Remove the stinger** if visible (use tweezers, not fingers).
2Ô∏è‚É£ **Wash the area** with soap and water.
3Ô∏è‚É£ **Apply a cold pack** to reduce swelling.
4Ô∏è‚É£ If there's **itching**, apply calamine lotion or an antihistamine cream.

‚ö†Ô∏è *If you see trouble breathing, swelling on face/throat, or dizziness ‚Äî call emergency help right away.
This might be an allergic reaction.*

eq.value: Insect sting or bite (bee, spider, mosquito, etc.)

concat.scalar:
***it‚Äôs a bite from an animal:***

1Ô∏è‚É£ **Wash the wound thoroughly** with soap and clean water for at least 5 minutes.
2Ô∏è‚É£ **Apply antiseptic** (Betadine/Savlon).
3Ô∏è‚É£ Cover with a sterile bandage.
4Ô∏è‚É£ **Visit a doctor immediately** ‚Äî rabies vaccination may be needed.

üí° *Even small bites can be serious. Don‚Äôt skip medical help.*

*it's a snake bite, stay calm and do the following:*

1Ô∏è‚É£ **Keep the bitten part still and lower than the heart.**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **Don‚Äôt walk or run** ‚Äî ask for help to reach medical care.
3Ô∏è‚É£ **Do NOT suck the venom**, cut the wound, or apply ice.
4Ô∏è‚É£ **Remove tight items** like rings or bracelets.

üöë *Go to the hospital immediately.

*
üß™ *Try to remember the color or shape of the snake ‚Äî this can help doctors.*

I didn't catch that. Select a valid option:

*If someone faints or becomes unconscious:*

1Ô∏è‚É£ **Lay them down flat** and **raise their legs** slightly.
2Ô∏è‚É£ **Loosen tight clothing** (collars, belts).
3Ô∏è‚É£ **Check for breathing** ‚Äî if normal, let them rest.
4Ô∏è‚É£ **Do NOT splash water** or crowd around.

üö® *If they don‚Äôt regain consciousness in 1 minute,

or stop breathing ‚Äî call emergency help*

**G*iven below is*** **National Ambulance Service (NAS) Number** ***:- 102***

‚ù§Ô∏è *If someone has chest pain and you suspect a heart attack:*

1Ô∏è‚É£ Ask them to **sit down and stay calm**.
2Ô∏è‚É£ If available, give them **one Aspirin** (unless allergic).
3Ô∏è‚É£ **Loosen tight clothes** and reassure them.
4Ô∏è‚É£ **Call emergency services immediately .**

‚ö†Ô∏è *Do NOT give water or food.*

***TRY TO GET A DOCTOR AS SOON AS POSSIBLE***
**G*iven below is*** **National Ambulance Service (NAS) Number** ***:- 102***

‚ö° *If someone is having a seizure:*

1Ô∏è‚É£ **Stay calm** and **do not hold them down**.
2Ô∏è‚É£ **Clear the area** to prevent injury.
3Ô∏è‚É£ **Turn them on their side** after the seizure ends.
4Ô∏è‚É£ **Do not put anything in their mouth.**

**‚è±Ô∏è** ***If seizure lasts more than 5 minutes ‚Äî seek emergency help.***
**G*iven below is*** **National Ambulance Service (NAS) Number** ***:- 102***

**üß†** ***Think FAST:***


  - **Face drooping?**
  - **Arm weakness?**
  - **Speech difficulty?**
  - **Time to call help!**

**Please choose the condition your child :**
I didn't catch that. Select a valid option:
**What's your child age ?**
I didn't catch that. Select a valid option:

> ‚ö†Ô∏è **If the baby is silent, turning red/blue, or not breathing:**




  1. **Lay the baby face down** on your forearm.
  2. Give **5 back blows** between the shoulder blades using the heel of your hand.
  3. Turn the baby face up and give **5 chest thrusts** using two fingers (same as CPR, but gentler).
  4. Repeat until the object is expelled or help arrives.
  5.
Call emergency services if unresponsive.

> ‚ö†Ô∏è *If the child cannot talk, breathe, or is clutching the throat:*




  1. Ask, *"Are you choking?"* If yes, proceed.
  2. Stand behind them, make a fist, and place it just above their belly button.
  3. Give **5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver)** inward and upward.
  4. Repeat until the object comes out.
  5. If the child becomes unconscious ‚Üí start **CPR** and call emergency services.

> **üî• If a child is burned by hot water, food, or objects:**




  1. **Immediately run cool (not ice-cold) water** over the area for **10-20 minutes**.
  2. Do **not apply ice, toothpaste, or butter**.
  3. Cover the burn loosely with a **clean cloth or sterile dressing**.
  4. **Do not break blisters.**
  5. Take the child to a doctor if:
‚Ä£ The burn is deep
‚Ä£ On face, hands,

genitals
‚Ä£ Larger than the child‚Äôs palm

> üå°Ô∏è *If the child has high fever (over 100.4¬∞F or 38¬∞C):*




  1. Use a thermometer to check the temperature.
  2. **Use a cold compress** on the forehead.
  3. Give **paracetamol** or doctor-recommended fever medicine.
  4. **Keep child hydrated** ‚Äì give water, ORS, or fluids.
  5. Do **not overdress** ‚Äì keep clothing light.
**Does the child has a febrile seizure**
I didn't catch that. Select a valid option:

### ‚ö†Ô∏è *If the child has a febrile seizure:*

  1. **Lay the child on their side** to prevent choking.
  2. **Do not hold or shake them.**
  3. **Do not put anything in their mouth.**
  4. Once the seizure ends (usually < 5 mins), let them rest.
  5. **Visit a doctor immediately.**
Is it a Falls / Head Bump or Nosebleed
I didn't catch that. Select a valid option:

ü§ï Head Injury / Fall:

> üß† *If the child falls or bumps their head:*




  1. Apply a **cold pack** on the bump to reduce swelling.
  2. Watch for **vomiting, dizziness, confusion, or drowsiness** ‚Äî seek medical help if these appear.
  3. Keep the child awake for a while and monitor.
  4. If unconscious or bleeding from ear/nose ‚Üí call emergency help

üëÉ Nosebleed:
1. **Sit the child upright** and lean their head **slightly forward**. 2. Pinch their nostrils together and hold for **10 minutes**. 3. **Don‚Äôt tilt the head back.** 4. Apply a **cold compress** to the bridge of the nose. 5. If bleeding doesn‚Äôt stop in 20 minutes ‚Üí see a doctor.
